column4: Q: I have a script i want to run at startup... where do i call it from?
/etc/init.d/rcS would work. Or you could put it in /etc/init.d and symlink to it from /etc/rc?.d to mix it in with the rest of the services
you mean just put the script in the direcotry /etc/init.d ?
^^ is easiest
to set order, you put the script in /etc/init.d, then create a symlink in the runlevel you want it to run it
is tha tthe same as nickrud's answer?
for example, ln -s /etc/init.d/myscript /etc/rc2.d/S99myscript
that will have myscript run at '99' in runlevel two
using K99myscript instead of S99myscript will have myscript stopped at 99 instead of started
to go that route, though. I think you're script needs to support being called with 'start' or 'stop' as a command line parameter
that will run it when you log in, rather than when the system boots
and only when you log into gnome, at that
the script just sets up network interface settings...
oooohhhh so no good when logging into kde / fluxbox? hmmm
is it something that the existing networking support can't handle?
not really, but i've been having problems with Networking. My interface seems alot happier if I use the command line. (airport + Dapper..)
just so I know I'm not giving you bad info, what were you referring to by 'Sessions'. I took it to mean the app that loads from going to System->Preferences->Sessions in Gnome
yea, thats exactly what I meant. I"m finding tho that I'm learning way more about how to configure my system by using command lines and scripts - besides, its geekily-good fun!!
